item.title: CNRS | 125 million year old dinosaur discovered with spikes identical to the porcupine
item.description: A new species of herbivorous dinosaur, which lived 125 million years ago and had spines comparable to those of a modern porcupine, was discovered in China, the French National Center for Scientific Research (CNRS) announced on Friday. In a statement, the CNRS stated that “until then, there was no evidence to prove the existence of such spines in dinosaurs” and explained that scientists named the new species ‘Haolong dongi’ in honor of Dong Zhiming, a pioneer of Chinese paleontology. The investigation into the discovery was published on Friday in the journal Nature Ecology & Evolution, reported the agency Efe. The discovery in China of the exceptionally well-preserved fossilized skin of a young Cretaceous iguanodon led CNRS scientists and their international partners to use high-resolution X-ray tomography and histological sections. The researchers were then able to observe skin cells preserved for 125 million years, which indicated the presence of hollow, horny spines on a large part of the body, comparable to those of modern porcupines in their defense function. These protuberances also demonstrate a hitherto unknown evolutionary defense mechanism in iguanodons, a group of dinosaurs that, depending on the species, could measure between 6 and 10 meters in length and weigh several tons. The study suggests that the spines played a role in thermoregulation (because they are hollow, they could have helped dissipate or absorb heat) or sensory perception (to detect movement or changes in the environment). “As the ‘Haolong dongi’ specimen is a juvenile, it is not yet known whether these spines were also present in adults,” the CNRS further noted.

item.title: National security | Calvin Chui defends new law
item.description: Calvin Chui, lawyer and president of the Macau Youth Federation, defended the Government's proposed law that will allow judicial representatives to be removed from any process that has elements understood to be relevant to national security. “The transformation [of the diploma] into a concrete legal system and the improvement of the high-level ‘architecture’ of the national security operating structure are in line with the fundamental requirements of Macau’s governance, in accordance with the law”, said Chui, son of deputy Chu Sai Peng and nephew of former Chief Executive Chui Sai ON, in statements cited by Canal Macau. “This approach also promotes the rule of law and the institutionalization and normalization of national security work, with the ultimate aim of establishing a more robust and stable legal safeguard for the long-term stability and sustained prosperity of the Macao SAR,” he added. According to the future requirements of the diploma that will still be voted on in the Legislative Assembly, the commission will have all the powers to veto the participation of lawyers in cases. In addition, judicial representatives must present detailed information about their lives, connections with the outside world and also their household.

item.title: Pearl Horizon | Only 338 residents purchased replacement units
item.description: Only 338 residents of the 1,923 affected by the non-construction of Pearl Horizon went ahead to purchase replacement apartments, made available by Macau Renovação Urbana. The data was released yesterday by the Chinese channel Radio Macau. The replacement apartments aimed to assist residents who were left without the apartments they were paying for when the Government recovered the land where the Pearl Horizon luxury development was to be built. The deadline for the purchase ended at the end of January, according to the order from the Chief Executive published in November last year. The number represents 17.6 percent of injured residents. The replacement apartments are located in the Pearl Metropolitan building, made up of six apartment blocks spanning 50 floors, providing 2,064 apartments.

item.title: Archive in Lisbon helps Brazilians confirm land ownership
item.description: The Overseas Historical Archive (AHU) of Portugal is still consulted today by Brazilians looking for proof that they are the owners of their lands in Brazil, distributed by the Portuguese five centuries ago, indicates the person responsible for this institution. “From time to time, we receive requests to hand over an authenticated document to a court, or to settle a dispute or conflict at that level, despite it being historical documentation,” Ana Canas, a researcher at the History Center of the University of Lisbon who has served as director of the AHU, told the Lusa agency. This documentation, physically present in the AHU, but already available on digital media, includes documents from the granting of sesmarias in Brazil, a land distribution system adopted by the Portuguese Crown, in the 16th century, in which land was donated to sesmeiros, so that they could occupy and produce on them. And it is this proof of land concession that its owners still seek at the AHU today, as it is there that the documentation resulting from the relationship between Brazil and the Portuguese administration resides, during the colonial period. Kilometers of papers The AHU, created in 1931 with the aim of safeguarding the repositories of the Portuguese colonial administration, stores around 17 kilometers of documentation, which portrays the relationship between the various territories (former Portuguese colonies) and the organizations based in Lisbon. Documents that have proven to be sources of information about these territories and their experiences: India, Brazil, Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, São Tomé and Príncipe, Timor-Leste and Macau. The Brazilian collection, located at the AHU facilities, which is located in the Palácio do Ega, in Lisbon, was the subject of the “Projecto Resgate Barão do Rio Branco”, an international archival cooperation program, whose mission is to catalog and reproduce the handwritten historical documentation relating to this country, until independence, in 1822. The Portuguese arrived in Brazil in 1500 and the occupation of the lands began in 1530. It is the history of this presence and the relationship with the Crown, in Portugal, until independence, that the documentation tells. For more than 10 years, around 120 researchers involved in this project worked on the 300,000 documents that are located at the AHU and that involve Brazil, which are now duly identified and distributed in more than 2,000 boxes, in addition to being available on digital media.

item.title: Lamborghini | Asian debut of the Temerario GT3 could be in Macau
item.description: Lamborghini said goodbye to the Huracán GT3 at the 2025 Macau Grand Prix and is now aiming for the Asian debut of the recently launched Temerario GT3, scheduled for November, on the streets of our city The ninth edition of the FIA ​​GT World Cup, scheduled for the 19th to 22nd of November at the Guia Circuit, appears as the likely stage for the debut on the Asian continent of the latest competition car from the Sant’Agata Bolognese brand, in a season in which the new twin-turbo V8 engine model will mainly be in a phase of competitive consolidation in Europe and the United States of America. Due to the limitations inherent in the production and delivery of new cars, Lamborghini Squadra Corse never seriously considered the introduction of the Temerario GT3 in the Asia-Pacific market in its launch year, despite the interest expressed by several teams, including JLOC, the formation of the Japanese Super GT championship that local driver André Couto represented. Even so, there is a clear desire on the part of Automobili Lamborghini's competition department to put its new GT3 on the track in Asia this year, precisely in the context of the Macau Grand Prix. “I can confirm that no Temerario will be entered in the GT World Challenge Asia or other regional championships,” explained a spokesperson for the Italian brand to the Portuguese portal SportMotores.com. "However, we are working on the FIA ​​GT World Cup in Macau, a race of enormous importance for us, where we intend to be present in the best possible way. At this stage, we cannot provide any further details." The possibility of Lamborghini competing this year in the Macao SAR race with the old Huracán GT3 is ruled out. The model faced difficulties in 2024 related to the introduction of the mandatory and controversial torque sensors. Edoardo Mortara had a particularly ungrateful weekend, seeing his third best time in Super Pole canceled for exceeding the maximum power limit, later ending up abandoning the main race when his car shut down. Production limitations Unlike other competition departments of major manufacturers, the Lamborghini Squadra Corse is a relatively small structure. The main limiting factor in the implementation of the Temerario GT3 this season, especially outside Europe, is related not only to the availability of units, but above all to the priority given to adequate technical support from the factory. The United States of America, where the car will make its competition debut at the 12 Hours of Sebring in March, continues to assume a strategic role for Lamborghini, hence the brand's full-time presence in the IMSA SportsCar Championship through the Pfaff Motorsports team. For the current season, Lamborghini Squadra Corse has allocated seven examples of the Temerario GT3 to competition in Europe, divided between the GT World Challenge Europe and the DTM. The Italian manufacturer plans to field three cars in the GT World Challenge Europe and four in the DTM. Mercedes-AMG evaluates return The absence of Mercedes-AMG in last year's edition was one of the most talked about topics in the paddock. This decision was justified by the lack of opportunities for Asian client teams to test the complex torque sensors, at a stage in which the Stuttgart brand is going through a demanding process of transitioning its sporting activities from HWA to the new subsidiary Affalterbach Racing. “At this stage, it is not possible to say whether a Mercedes-AMG GT3 will compete in the FIA ​​GT World Cup in Macau in 2026,” an official source from the German manufacturer, who maintains high interest in the MSAR event, told Hoje Macau. "The race is extremely appealing, both from a sporting and strategic point of view. We will carefully analyze the conditions at the appropriate time and evaluate them together with the interested teams." It should also be noted that the Macau Grand Prix could symbolize the definitive goodbye of the current Mercedes-AMG GT3, as the star brand is already developing the next generation of its car for the category, whose debut in competition could take place in 2027.

item.title: Cooperation | Coimbra and Macau with research program
item.description: The academic collaboration program between universities in the two cities will focus on promoting Sino-Portuguese studies and includes the digitization of historical archives The University of Coimbra and the Polytechnic University of Macau launched a research program in Digital Humanities, focused on promoting Sino-Portuguese studies, which includes the digitization of historical archives, announced the Chinese institution. The initiative aims to “further develop Macau's role as a bridge for academic exchange between China and Portuguese-speaking countries and deepen international cooperation in interdisciplinary scientific research”, reads a statement from the Macau Polytechnic University (UPM). The new program, officially launched this week, will bring together “the advantages of the two universities” to “develop multidimensional research innovations”, focusing on “promoting Sino-Portuguese humanities studies, including the digitization of historical archives, research and development in large-scale Portuguese language models and artificial intelligence, the digital revitalization of cultural heritage, as well as contemporary digital communication”. Also according to the statement, the vice-rector of the University of Coimbra (UC), Nuno Mendonça, said at the time that, with artificial intelligence profoundly changing research and teaching, “the rise of digital humanities is not only a technical challenge, but also a profound dialogue that involves ethics and culture”. “With centuries of experience in studying Chinese culture, the UC serves as an academic bridge between East and West, with the aim of integrating linguistic technologies, creative industries and research into cultural heritage through this program”, said Mendonça, quoted in the note. Academic laboratories In the future, the two universities will cooperate to create academic laboratories that “will pioneer technological innovation on the campus in Hengqin, a space that symbolizes the fusion between tradition and innovation”, he reinforced. The two educational institutions signed an agreement “to establish a base of cooperation in the field of higher education in the ‘International Education (University) City of Macau and Hengqin’, in order to build an ‘international campus’ oriented towards the global community”, recalled, in turn, the rector of UPM. In this sense, said Marcus Im, the new program takes on a significant mission. Focusing on “language and text technologies and digital applications”, and through “building a database of interlingual texts, it promotes data innovation in the human and social sciences”. On the other hand, through digital exhibitions and interactive experiences, “it encourages the dissemination and sharing of multicultural resources”, stated the rector of UPM, also mentioned in the note. The new campus of the Macau Polytechnic University will be integrated into a university city, which will also include the new campus of the University of Macau, whose work began in December last year. In the presentation of the Lines of Government Action for 2026, at the end of last year, the local government stated that, in a first phase, the University of Macau, the Polytechnic University of Macau and the University of Tourism of Macau will establish themselves in the location, “expected to begin teaching activities from September 2026, with the number of students set at 1,200, in the first year, and with a predominance of postgraduate.”

item.title: Concerts | South Korean group takes the stage without Japanese singer
item.description: Japanese singer Shotaro was left out of Riize's two concerts in Macau, which was justified by “unforeseeable circumstances”. Macau authorities have not officially commented, but in South Korea reports indicate the existence of a boycott of artists from the Japanese country. The organization of Riize's two concerts in Macau, which took place over the weekend, confirmed that the South Korean male group performed without Japanese singer Shotaro, at a time of tension between Beijing and Tokyo. Riize, who currently have six members, took to the stage at the Galaxy Arena, at the Galaxy Macau hotel-casino, with just five artists, said the company IME Macau. In a statement published on social media and cited by the Portuguese-language public television channel TDM – Teledifusao de Macau, the company justified the decision with “unforeseeable circumstances”, without further details. Asked on Tuesday about the cancellation of shows with Japanese artists, the director of the Macau Tourism Office said she had “no concrete information about the situation”. Maria Helena de Senna Fernandes was speaking on the sidelines of the Lunar New Year parade, which celebrates the Year of the Horse. Unlike previous years, there will be no groups from Japan. On January 28, South Korean broadcaster MBC, which was organizing the ‘Show! Music Core in Macau’, a music festival in South Korea, which included bands featuring Japanese artists, canceled the event. The festival was also scheduled for last weekend, at the Open Air Performance Site, in the Cotai area, created by the Macao SAR Government. MBC did not provide any explanation for the decision, saying only that it was taken “after a thorough analysis of local circumstances and general logistical conditions”. Apparently Even before the official announcement by MBC, the South Korean press had already discussed the possible cancellation due to the alleged difficulty of Japanese artists in obtaining visas to perform in Macau. Lusa tried to confirm this information with the Immigration Services of the Public Security Police, the Cultural Institute (IC) of Macau and the Labor Affairs Bureau, but received no response. On December 12, the president of the IC denied any interference in the cancellation of concerts with Japanese artists scheduled for the region and assured that these were solely commercial decisions by the organizers. “I think different parties have their own weighting factors,” said Leong Wai Man, at a press conference. "It is normal to have adjustments regarding concerts or different events. Situations of cancellation due to force majeure are common", he added. Asked by Lusa whether there were instructions from the Government not to hold cultural events with artists from Japan, Leong Wai Man assured that “this is a question for the commercial sector, it is the organizer's decision” “I have nothing more to add”, stressed the leader. In December, shows with Japanese artists had been canceled in at least three different hotel-casinos in Macau. In November, the Prime Minister of Japan spoke in the Japanese parliament about possible Japanese military intervention in a conflict between mainland China and Taiwan. Sanae Takaichi stated that if an emergency situation in Taiwan involved “the deployment of warships and the use of force, this could constitute a threat to Japan’s survival.” Days later, Beijing advised against traveling to Japan, an example later followed by the semi-autonomous regions of Macau and Hong Kong. Contrary to usual, the Hong Kong Government did not send any representatives to an event organized by the Japanese consulate on Thursday, to mark the birthday of Japanese Emperor Naruhito, according to the Hong Kong Free Press news portal.

item.title: Mental Health | Deputies ask for better monitoring of students
item.description: With the number of requests for help from students rising, deputies Lam Lon Wai and Loi I Weng want more commitment from the Government to improve mental health, and call for the use of artificial intelligence Deputies Lam Lon Wai and Loi I Weng advocate the use of newer technologies, mainly artificial intelligence, to monitor the mental health of young people in Macau. This is how legislators reacted to the most recent data published by the Juvenile Monitoring Section of the Judicial Police. According to authorities, last year 250 requests for assistance were made by minors with symptoms of emotional disturbance or stress, which corresponded to an increase of 64 percent year on year. The increase was the sharpest in the Macao SAR since there are records. In a statement, Lam Lon Wai, who is also deputy director of the Secondary School for Workers' Sons and Brothers, argued that to ensure the healthy growth of students, it is necessary to establish a cooperation mechanism between family, school, Government and society. The deputy stated that the family is the first line of defense, so parents should pay more attention to their children's changes in mood, their friendships, and internet use, particularly during long holidays. The deputy director also indicated that parents must monitor their children very closely to identify signs of risk. Role of schools Furthermore, Lam Lon Wai pointed out that schools must continue to invest in education for life, mental health and legal education for young people, so that students develop correct values, as members of society. From Lam's perspective, this role must be complemented by the Government and society by strengthening support for mental health and developing help channels. Promotion must use social media to be more comprehensive. For her part, the deputy and also deputy director of the General Women's Association School, Loi I Weng, argues that the Government should use artificial intelligence to monitor the mental health of young people in schools, through data collection and analysis, to identify and intervene in potential cases. The official also hopes that the Government will provide schools with more resources to alleviate the workload of assistants who are on the front line and to increase the quality and effectiveness of these monitoring services. The issue of mental health gained predominance during the pandemic and post-pandemic years, with data growing steadily. Authorities dealt with this increase by opting out of releasing statistics.

item.title: Research | Epstein and Bannon discussed Wynn and Adelson’s “weaknesses”
item.description: Macau appears in more than 200 files in the “Epstein Library”, mostly in articles relating to casino revenue and the investment environment. However, conversations with Steve Bannon emerge about Trump's lack of respect towards Steve Wynn and Sheldon Adelson, as well as notes from a sexual predator about a visit to Macau With millions of files still to be released, and with the last update made last Friday, Macau appears in 208 files in the so-called “Epstein Library” on the US Department of Justice portal. Throughout the more than two hundred files, references to Macau are divided between innocuous invitations to open art exhibitions resulting from artistic residencies in the Macao SAR, “briefings” with economic news and about Sheldon Adelson's business in Macau, sent by dubious characters to say the least, reports on the business environment and gambling revenues and trips to the territory. HM analyzed the files released so far, diving between purely financial information and sordid allusions. One of the most interesting conversations, dated January 1, 2019, features Jeffrey Epstein himself and political operative and podcaster Steve Bannon. Among political contiguities, Epstein states that the American Democratic Party would be using a law that requires registration as a foreign agent to attack Steve Wynn. A tactic described as “potent”. And then he says that “Donald doesn't respect him at all, nothing at all”, referring to the founder of Wynn Resorts. After Bannon's agreement, Epstein continues to state: “the same in relation to Adelson”, adding the fragile position of those who have “interests in Macau”. "Way worse than fragile, buried in shit. They already threw your contact from a 40-story building," adds Bannon. The MAGA movement operative and strategist in Trump's first term as President of the United States does not specify who was “thrown” from the building, but the conversation between Bannon and Epstein took place just over two months after the alleged suicide of Zheng Xiaosong, director of the Central Government Liaison Office in Macau. Zheng died after falling from Block 2 of the Hung On Center, on Rua de Luís Gonzaga Gomes. Beijing issued a short statement stating that he was suffering from depression, suggesting that it was a case of suicide. Remember that at this time Jeffrey Epstein had already been convicted of crimes of a sexual nature and Steve Bannon was “helping” the tycoon to rehabilitate his public image, in the midst of the campaign for the elections won by Joe Biden. Macau, an inspiration Still in the conversation between Steve Bannon and Epstein, it is indicated that Steve Wynn has a “huge problem with Kwok”, who Epstein refers to as “your boy”. According to the Justice Department's investigation into Steve Wynn, in 2022 during the Biden Administration, Bannon's “boy” will be Miles Kwok, or Guo Wengui, a Chinese dissident businessman exiled in the United States. The founder of Wynn Resorts reportedly tried to influence the White House in 2017, during Donald Trump's first term, to repatriate Miles Kwok to face corruption charges in China. Despite Trump's alleged disrespect towards Wynn and Adelson, the two gambling businessmen contributed many millions of dollars to the campaigns of the current President of the United States. From a much lighter perspective, on a scale of weak morality, in April 2014, Jeffrey Epstein receives an email from his long-time assistant Lesleu Groff with an invitation to the opening of the exhibition “Classic Artwork from Macau”, at the New York Academic of Art. The exhibition was the result of an invitation from the Macao SAR Government, through the Directorate of Tourism Services, to 10 artists based in the United States. The idea would be to take advantage of an artistic residency in the territory to capture the beauty of Macau. Of the 10 artists chosen, three were students at the New York Academic of Art, an institution that had Epstein in its administration. Despite the lighter perspective of this detail in the files, it is important to note that Epstein's accomplice, Ghislaine Maxwell, recruited victims among the academy's students. In the published files it is not indicated whether Epstein visited the art exhibition inspired by Macau. Rot and finances The vast majority of mentions of Macau in documents released by the Department of Justice concern opinion pieces and financial news about the business environment in Macau, gambling revenue from local dealerships, and articles about Sheldon Adelson's connections to the Republican Party. Most of the emails containing this type of information were sent by an assistant to the deceased sexual predator, but also by other characters. In addition to receiving reports from Deutsche Bank Securities, including on the development of infrastructure in the region (such as the Delta Bridge, Zhuhai's connection to the high-speed rail line and the Light Rail) and its expected impact on Macau's economy, Epstein received articles sent by Terje Rød-Larsen and Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem with information about the Macao SAR. The first is a Norwegian politician and diplomat, who since leaving public office has dedicated himself to uniting the North American MAGA movement and European far-right parties. Rød-Larsen sent a collection of articles, some of them about Sheldon Adelson. The second is a businessman from the United Arab Emirates, who shared with Epstein sordid details about his sexual adventures with women, but who also sent articles about the Macau casino industry. Some emails appear with the emissary erased, with an email from September 2012 in which it is stated that “Macau is becoming super interesting”, in a message about the GDP growth of the Comoros Archipelago, on the southeast coast of Africa. However, in addition to economic and political information, in the files in which Macau is mentioned, messages from Jean-Luc Brunel, a sexual predator who operated as the owner of a modeling agency, and who allegedly committed suicide in prison before being tried, appear. The similarities with Epstein's death go further, with hanging allegedly being the method used by both. In December 2013, Brunel told Epstein that he was leaving for Macau, describing the city as “rat hunting territory”. When he arrives, the Frenchman says that “Macau is more horrible than horrible”. However, two days later, Brunel says “Las Vegas looks like a small, chic city”, without punctuation. There are no further details in the files about Jean-Luc Brunel's time in Macau.

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. One of the chapters deals with philanthropy in Macau, the discreet profile of philanthropists and the work of entities such as Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino and Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and the historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”. "There are those who do not agree with me regarding the idea that the Portuguese language is a language of unity, not only among Portuguese-speaking peoples, but even within each country. We have the case of Timor-Leste, which on the island of Ataúro alone, which is very small, with 500 thousand inhabitants, has 40 dialects, one in each village. There, what does the Portuguese language do? It unites these people, because despite there being a difference between the who speak and those who learned Portuguese, in Timor-Leste, today, the elderly speak Portuguese and young people too, but there is the age group that goes from 25 to 50, who do not speak it. But, because it is a language of learning, because it is official, because it has books, a memory, Portuguese unites all these ethnicities and dialects, and has a common value, because the Portuguese language is everyone's mother tongue”, he explains. José Manuel Simões does not forget the work that CPLP – Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, has done in this regard. "The CPLP had a wonderful idea of ​​uniting us through language, but the CPLP has done vague, limited and barely visible work. In fact, very few people have done a worthy job of creating links between new Portuguese-speaking cultures. In this sense, this book fills a gap and brings new data about these new cultures, with this technological and innovative dynamic", this in relation to the QR codes for all chapters of the book. Each code gives access to a video that summarizes the author's work in each chapter. In global terms, “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” aims to be comprehensive in areas such as technology, art, culture and social communication. There is, however, “a common denominator, creating, curiously, a certain harmony, even with different focuses, and ends up covering, directly and indirectly, the spectrum of social communication”, he concludes.

item.title: National security | Calvin Chui defends new law
item.description: Calvin Chui, lawyer and president of the Macau Youth Federation, defended the Government's proposed law that will allow judicial representatives to be removed from any process that has elements understood to be relevant to national security. “The transformation [of the diploma] into a concrete legal system and the improvement of the high-level ‘architecture’ of the national security operating structure are in line with the fundamental requirements of Macau’s governance, in accordance with the law”, said Chui, son of deputy Chu Sai Peng and nephew of former Chief Executive Chui Sai ON, in statements cited by Canal Macau. “This approach also promotes the rule of law and the institutionalization and normalization of national security work, with the ultimate aim of establishing a more robust and stable legal safeguard for the long-term stability and sustained prosperity of the Macao SAR,” he added. According to the future requirements of the diploma that will still be voted on in the Legislative Assembly, the commission will have all the powers to veto the participation of lawyers in cases. In addition, judicial representatives must present detailed information about their lives, connections with the outside world and also their household.

item.title: Archive in Lisbon helps Brazilians confirm land ownership
item.description: The Overseas Historical Archive (AHU) of Portugal is still consulted today by Brazilians looking for proof that they are the owners of their lands in Brazil, distributed by the Portuguese five centuries ago, indicates the person responsible for this institution. “From time to time, we receive requests to hand over an authenticated document to a court, or to settle a dispute or conflict at that level, despite it being historical documentation,” Ana Canas, a researcher at the History Center of the University of Lisbon who has served as director of the AHU, told the Lusa agency. This documentation, physically present in the AHU, but already available on digital media, includes documents from the granting of sesmarias in Brazil, a land distribution system adopted by the Portuguese Crown, in the 16th century, in which land was donated to sesmeiros, so that they could occupy and produce on them. And it is this proof of land concession that its owners still seek at the AHU today, as it is there that the documentation resulting from the relationship between Brazil and the Portuguese administration resides, during the colonial period. Kilometers of papers The AHU, created in 1931 with the aim of safeguarding the repositories of the Portuguese colonial administration, stores around 17 kilometers of documentation, which portrays the relationship between the various territories (former Portuguese colonies) and the organizations based in Lisbon. Documents that have proven to be sources of information about these territories and their experiences: India, Brazil, Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, São Tomé and Príncipe, Timor-Leste and Macau. The Brazilian collection, located at the AHU facilities, which is located in the Palácio do Ega, in Lisbon, was the subject of the “Projecto Resgate Barão do Rio Branco”, an international archival cooperation program, whose mission is to catalog and reproduce the handwritten historical documentation relating to this country, until independence, in 1822. The Portuguese arrived in Brazil in 1500 and the occupation of the lands began in 1530. It is the history of this presence and the relationship with the Crown, in Portugal, until independence, that the documentation tells. For more than 10 years, around 120 researchers involved in this project worked on the 300,000 documents that are located at the AHU and that involve Brazil, which are now duly identified and distributed in more than 2,000 boxes, in addition to being available on digital media.

item.title: Concert | OneRepublic perform in Hong Kong this month
item.description: The North American band OneRepublic is returning to Asia for a series of concerts, highlighting their trip to the AsiaWorld-Expo stage on the 17th for the “OneRepublic – From Asia, With Love in Hong Kong” tour. Performances will follow in China, Korea and Japan Asian fans of North Americans OneRepublic will soon have the opportunity to see them up close again. After a visit to Macau in 2024, the group will return to Asia, but this time to neighboring Hong Kong, to perform as part of the “OneRepublic – From Asia, With Love in Hong Kong” tour. This show is scheduled for the 17th of this month at AsiaWorld-Expo. Organized by LiveNation, the concert takes place from 8pm and promises to bring the greatest hits from the band that has already been nominated for a Grammy, namely “Counting Stars”, “Apologize”, “I Ain’t Worried” and “Run”. The synopsis of the show, published on the AsiaWorld-Expo portal, states that the band “continues to captivate millions of fans around the world with their characteristic sound and sincere narratives”, and, during their visit to Hong Kong, fans can expect “an electrifying night of music, energy and connection”, in a collective celebration of “the group's greatest hits and new works”. The “From Asia, With Love” tour aims to be “a special celebration of OneRepublic’s strong connection with its Asian fans, highlighting the region as one of the band’s most passionate audiences”, with Hong Kong “being one of the main stops on this exclusive tour”. After visiting the neighboring region, the band continues their trip, on the 23rd, to Seoul, South Korea; followed by performances in Tokyo, on the 25th, and Kobe, on the 27th. In March, it is OneRepublic's turn to travel to another show taking place in Singapore, on the 2nd; followed by Taipei, Taiwan, on March 4th. Concerts in China follow on April 17th, 19th and 25th in the cities of Shenzhen, Wuhan and Shanghai, respectively. OneRepublic continues to tour the rest of the world, particularly with concerts in Mexico and Europe, in countries such as Italy, Luxembourg, Spain and Scotland. Successes since 2000 OneRepublic emerged in 2002 in Colorado Springs presenting themselves as a group of pop rock and alternative rock songs, starting to be successful on the social network MySpace, which has since disappeared. In 2006, the band managed to sign a contract with the record label Mosley Music Group, releasing their debut album, “Dreaming Out Loud”. At that time they achieved international success, thanks to the single “Apologize”, which featured the contribution of rapper and producer Timbaland; and also the single “Stop and Stare”. This album sold more than three million copies worldwide. After several years of recording and being on the road, OneRepublic participated, in 2022, on the soundtrack of the film that revived the cinema classic “Top Gun”, starring Tom Cruise. On the album that contains all the songs from “Top Gun: Maverick” the band participates with “I Ain’t Worried”, alongside names like Lady Gaga or Lorne Balfe. After the release of “Artificial Paradise” in 2024, the group returned to new songs in December last year with the single “Give Me Something”, made for the game “Arknights Endfield”. This song was produced by band members Ryan Tedder, Brent Kutzle and Simon Oscroft.

item.title: South Sea | Beijing carries out air and naval patrols
item.description: Beijing revealed yesterday that it carried out air and naval patrols in the disputed South China Sea, in response to joint exercises carried out in January by the Philippines and the United States in these disputed waters. The spokesperson for the Southern Theater Command of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) said that the patrols took place between February 2 and 6, without providing further details about the air and naval assets involved. “In an attempt to provoke instability in the South China Sea, the Philippine side allied itself with countries outside the region and carried out so-called ‘bilateral air patrols’, which undermine regional peace and stability,” lamented Zhai Shichen. In a statement, the spokesperson highlighted that Chinese forces “will remain on high alert” and “firmly defend China's territorial sovereignty and maritime rights and interests”. The maneuvers followed those carried out by Beijing, in the same waters, on January 25 and 26, after the Philippines and the United States organized a joint navigation exercise at Scarborough Atoll. This atoll is known as Huangyan in China and Bajo de Masinloc in the Philippines, which ensure that the area is within Manila's exclusive economic zone. China claims sovereignty over virtually the entire South China Sea, a strategic region through which approximately 30 percent of global maritime trade passes and which contains important fishing areas and potential hydrocarbon reserves.

item.title: East Timor | NGO helps doctors carry out internships in Macau
item.description: The GX Foundation has supported students from Timor-Leste to undertake medical internships in Hong Kong and Macau, the president of the non-governmental organization (NGO) said yesterday. Leung Chun-ying explained that GX, based in Hong Kong, has provided financial support to allow medical students from the Timor Lorosa’e National University to travel to one of the two Chinese regions. In an interview with Hong Kong public broadcaster RTHK, the former leader of the territory's government said that the foundation has expanded its work to ten countries on four continents, offering eight different types of assistance. Leung said GX has signed agreements with three local higher education institutions: the University of Hong Kong, Chinese University and Polytechnic University. The aim, explained the former HK Chief Executive, is to help students participate in humanitarian work, so that they can learn “benevolence” in Hong Kong and “compassion” abroad. Leung argued that, faced with major changes in the international panorama, China needs not only to consolidate existing friendships with other countries, but also to make new ones. In October 2024, the executive director of GX, Emily Chan Ying-yang, told Lusa that the foundation wanted to apply in other countries, starting with Honduras, a project that reversed the rapid growth of dengue fever in Timor-Leste. Between January and July, GX installed more than 1,670 anti-mosquito lamps and distributed almost 30 thousand adhesive tapes to catch insects, close to 18 thousand rapid dengue detection tests and around 500 anti-mosquito nets, in the 14 Timorese municipalities.

item.title: Paulo Maia e Carmo
item.description: Jiang Shinian, also known as Shennong, the «Divine Farmer», patron saint of practitioners of traditional medicine (zhongyi), is also known as Yandi, the «emperor of flames» and is therefore able to control the «flaming wind», the excess heat that causes symptoms such as tremors, confusion or sudden fever. In religious practice, this “fire in the wind” is understood as the smoke that results from the burning of incense or papers that carry prayers, offerings or messages to the gods, ancestors or spirits up to the heavens. This fire, represented by the color red, is associated, among others, with immortality, positive energy forces or protection against evil. Shades of the color red were notoriously adopted by the emperors of the Ming dynasty who had Zhu, “vermilion or cinnabar” as their family name. One of the most publicly manifest examples was painting the walls of the “Forbidden Imperial City”, Zijincheng, purple, as a form of protection for the occupants inside, or giving the clothing of literate officials the color of cinnabar. When the dynasty fell and for many literati it became intolerable to obey the new emperors, some adopted the most diverse and subtle strategies of resistance. A scholar from the North who, in the plurality of his knowledge and vocations, came to use more than thirty names of brush, created for himself the name Zhuyi daoren, the «Daoist dressed in cinnabar» as if by using this protective color, he only recognized his own body as the only border or wall. In ordinary life, his name was Fu Shan (1607-1684), born in Yangqu, Shanxi, and from his refusal to serve his new masters, which harmed his day-to-day life, countless talents emerged, still celebrated today in two gardens in the city of Taiyuan, the provincial capital. And although all the literati who knew him recognized his qualities as a calligrapher, painter or poet, those closest to him saw him as a practitioner of traditional medicine, in particular as an expert on women's illnesses. Fu Shan preferred his handwriting to be “rough, not skillful; ugly, not seductive; deformed, not thin; spontaneous, not premeditated». And just like in paintings, he liked long vertical formats, as can be seen in a couplet in the Smithonian (ink on paper, 226 x 45.5 cm) where, reflecting his dual concern with the spirit and the body, he wrote: «If the spirit is calm, the mind naturally reaches the distance; The more relaxed your body is, the more of life you will be able to enjoy». He is credited with creating an “eight treasure soup”, made with eight ingredients that restored the most weakened. And yet, when he was forced to go to court in Beijing for the ritual of obedience to the new dynasty, he threw himself to the ground, suffering an incapacitating illness. Walking along the riverbank, enjoying the flowers, 6 (out of 7): Access to Huangsi's in-laws' house it is full of flowers everywhere, There are a thousand, ten thousand flowers pressing the branches, so full, bent. Repeatedly invite the butterflies to stay constantly dancing, I listen to orioles: how they are tuned in your delicate chirp. Du Fu (712-770)

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official opening is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

item.title: History | Book reveals how Macau was created in the image of Évora
item.description:
The local association Heritage Society has just released a two-volume book on the history of Macau's founding. Authored by Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau”, contains translations and annotations of documents that show how the founding of Macau had Évora as a model
A book, divided into two volumes, has just been published by the local association Heritage Society, which helps tell the story of the founding of Macau, from the mid-16th century onwards. The two volumes are entitled “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau: Évora of the Far East” and “The Twenty-eight Alvarás”, and are authored by academics Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos. The first volume, which establishes a curious connection between Macau and Évora in the founding of the territory to the East, is based on the archive “Foral, Regalias e Privilégios Concedidos à Cidade de Macau, na China, 1596-1756”, the original of which is kept at the National Archives of Rio de Janeiro, and there are microfilms at the Macau Archive. In turn, the part dedicated to the 28 charters, a continuation of the first volume, analyzes the 28 legal texts initially decreed by the then governor of Macau and viceroy of India, D. Rodrigo da Costa, in 1689. These documents were later confirmed by King D. João V, in Portugal, in 1709. As the authors told HM, in a joint email interview, the first volume “deals with the first part of the archive, or the first 17 sheets, which concern the oldest founding letters, letters and sentences received by the Senate of Macau during the last years of the 16th century”. The second volume analyzes the contents of the file between pages 17 and 33, covering the 28 permits. “This is not yet the complete story, as we intend to continue working on the remaining archive in future years”, confessed the authors. The authors highlight the importance of the charter, an ancient document that consisted of “a charter or contract that the governing power, be it a feudal lord, a bishop or a king, establishes with a local entity, be it a village or city, a senate or a council”. "We consider that the word and the concept are important to reflect on this historical period and not only in Macau, but also the time when the European kingdom [Portugal] was at the height of its expansion across the seas and oceans. The concept of charter implies the way in which a Portuguese social structure was being transplanted and rethought in Macau." In this way, the authors add, all documents analyzed for these two volumes are related to the idea of ​​charter. In turn, the designation “City of the Name of God of Macau” appears, in this specific file, “not only in the charter of King Philip I of Portugal, during the Iberian Union, which stipulates the elevation of Macau from a town to a city, but also throughout the 28 subsequent charters”. In concrete terms, readers can come across “a research work that addresses some of the most important documents in the history of Macau, documents that inform us about the founding of the city and the evolution of its legal and governing tradition”. The connection with Évora The first volume of the work includes the subtitle “Évora of the Far East”, relating “the story in which the town's Senate presented a petition to the Viceroy of India for the recognition of the Senate, for the elevation of this port to the status of city and for the granting to the 'new city' of Macau of the privileges, rights and freedoms of the city of Évora”. D. Duarte de Meneses, at the time governor of Macau and viceroy of India, ended up granting this request on behalf of King D. Filipe I, in 1586, a “decision that was later confirmed by the king himself in 1595”. “To confirm and corroborate that Macau had the same status as Évora, it became natural that all the founding documents of the city of Évora were transcribed to Macau, so that the Senate of Macau could preserve them as evidence and keep them in its archives as founding documents of the city”, explain the authors. The documents found in the archive based in Rio de Janeiro point out that “the ‘proof’ of Macau’s status as a city comparable to Évora does not consist of a single document, but a compilation of several texts”. In the first volume of the work there are examples such as “sentences on the jurisdiction of certain positions, such as the Prosecutor and the Almotacé, royal letters on specific issues, laws on which positions should be part of a Senate, rites of religious and funeral processions and even the configuration of the Senate room”. In short, “everything that Évora possessed de jure during this period was inherited by Macau, as proven by the meticulous transcription and authentication of these documents”, explain the authors. The survival permits Regarding the second volume of the work, focused on the 28 permits, the authors understand that these documents “are particularly significant because they present themselves as a cohesive set, with great integrity in terms of language, format, administration and argumentation”. For Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, this results from the fact that, at the end of the 17th century, Macau was no longer in its golden period of trade, “due to the loss of commercial routes”. "At the same time, Macau faced constant social unrest, both internally – for example, between the Senate, the Captain-General and the Ouvidor – and externally, in relations with the Chinese and Castilians. The privileges and rights of the Senate were not respected, and it was necessary to resolve ambiguities to guarantee the city's survival, as reflected in the various minutes of the Senate meetings." Thus, a petition was presented by these bodies to governor D. Rodrigo da Costa “for the reaffirmation of the city's rights and to present solutions to various problems, such as the overflow of the jurisdiction of the Captain-General, the preservation of the Padroado in the face of foreign missionary groups and trade with the Chinese and in Solor and Timor”. Thus, the 28 permits emerged, which “also deal with a very diverse group of people from different arts, professions, origins and ideologies”, and not just relations between Portuguese and Chinese, which made “this set of documents particularly interesting to study”. The aim of publishing these two volumes was to facilitate access to the archive and its information. “We intend to place in the hands of Macau readers a fundamental document of the legal and political origin of the city, which remains little studied, even in Portuguese-speaking historiography, and which is almost completely absent from the daily historical imagination of Macau”, they add. The archive based in Rio de Janeiro was translated by the authors “and was never published in full, especially the founding documents related to Évora, not even in Portuguese”. This archive almost always appears “indirectly, as excerpts and paraphrases, such as those of canonical historians of Macau, in the case of Manuel Teixeira; or as references inserted in specialized works, and in some cases only through digitalized transcriptions that circulate in doctoral theses”. In the case of permits, they are “better known among historians, but appear only in very limited publications”. "For this reason, the publication of the primary text itself becomes essential. By presenting it in English and Chinese, alongside Portuguese, we also seek to remove a barrier that has long structured Macau's historiography, dividing the city's documentary past into separate linguistic archives that rarely dialogue with each other", they conclude. Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos also understand that “these volumes offer new answers in historiographical terms, because they show with renewed clarity that the legal existence of Macau emerged through the transplantation and local adaptation of the Portuguese municipality [Évora] as a governing idea on an Asian border”. “At its core, the archive poses a fundamental question that often remains implicit: what counted as ‘Portuguese territory’ in its smallest civic unit, and how could this unit be reconstructed overseas through privileges, positions and jurisdiction, after Portugal had become global from the 15th century onwards?” Local management Regarding the relationship between Portugal and China at the time, the authors state that the work shows how “relations between China and Portugal in Macau were not carried out mainly through formal diplomacy between two distant courts, but through the daily management of coexistence by local institutions, in conditions of unequal jurisdiction”. The first volume of the book shows how “the king elevated Macau from a town to a city and confirmed the elections of councillors, judges and officials because the Captain-Major appointed to China frequently left for the annual trip to Japan, remaining only a short time there and leaving the settlement without continuous leadership”. The original document reveals that “this situation was especially dangerous in China, given Macau's distance from India and the fact that supplies could only be made during the annual trip”. In this way, “municipal government is presented as a necessity: a frontier city could not wait for an absent commander nor could it allow disorder.” Thus, the authors add, “the privileges, jurisdiction and civic positions granted to Macau describe a political logic as much as a legal one, since the Portuguese presence depended on a permanent local body capable of maintaining peace and managing risks in a space where the superior authority was distant”. Regarding the permits, they show what maintaining the stability of the territory entailed, as “the survival of Macau depended on remaining within the limits tolerated by the Chinese authority”. "The Twenty-sixth Alvará, for example, is explicit in stating that the Chinese mandarinate did not accept Portuguese jurisdiction over Chinese subjects, especially when Christian creditors sought to arrest Chinese debtors. The Senate describes the expenses and dangers caused when a mandarin was sent to enforce such determinations and requests a direct solution: preventing Christians from contracting credits with the Chinese and denying them recourse to both the Ombudsman and the Chinese courts, so that the city could 'live in peace’. The Crown confirms this approach”, they conclude.

item.title: Elections | Portugal prepares to choose the next President of the Republic
item.description:
Portugal goes to the vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Republic. Of the 11 candidates, only two have representatives from Macau: Bessa Almeida from the PSD, and Neto Valente from the PS. The former president of the Macau Lawyers Association highlights that António José Seguro “does not join in provocations against China”, while Bessa Almeida considers that Marques Mendes is the right man for the moment
Eleven candidates will vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic, for a five-year term. This is a record number, with only seven having the support of political parties. Running for the position is Luís Marques Mendes, supported by the Social Democratic Party (PSD), and who appointed António Bessa Almeida as his representative in the Macao SAR. Next comes António José Seguro, with the support of the Socialist Party (PS), which has Jorge Neto Valente, president of the Macau Portuguese School Foundation and lawyer, as his representative. They are the only candidates for the Presidency of the Republic who chose figures as representatives of the Macao SAR. The remaining candidates are Henrique Gouveia e Melo, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Catarina Martins, António Filipe, André Ventura Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, André Pestana and Humberto Correia. To HM, António Bessa Almeida, PSD activist and explained the reasons for supporting Marques Mendes. “At the time Portugal is going through, the country needs a candidate like Marques Mendes, who has a deep understanding of the different policies”, he began by pointing out. Asked about the type of actions developed in Macau to attract the electorate to vote for Marques Mendes, Bessa Almeida simply mentioned that “the campaign in Macau is totally different from that in Portugal”, and the actions developed involve “what the candidate does in close proximity to the people, passing on information”. For Bessa Almeida, “the electorate in Macau, on the Chinese side, is also made up of Portuguese”, and that “they have been following these elections like any other Portuguese, with confident visions for the future of Portugal”. On January 6th, the president released a note highlighting the importance of Marques Mendes' candidacy, who is currently far from the top spots in the polls. "We have always been concerned with everything related to Portugal and at this moment, at a global level, political changes are sudden and unexpected. That is why we need a visionary president, experienced and thoughtful in guiding the destinies of Portugal and Portuguese people born and living outside the country."
A safe return In Portugal, polls relating to the presidential elections have taken place almost daily, and show a change in the choice of candidates. If initially António José Seguro was somewhat removed from the top positions, a survey carried out by the Universidade Católica Portuguesa for RTP, Antena 1 and the Público newspaper, between the 6th and 9th of January and released this week, shows how Seguro is in a technical tie with André Ventura, Chega's candidate, guaranteeing 23 percent of voting intentions, when Ventura collects 24 percent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo comes in third place, with 19 percent, with the possibility of going to the second round of elections, followed by Marques Mendes and Gouveia e Melo with 14 percent. Another survey, this time for TVI, CNN, TSF and Jornal de Notícias, with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January, shows Seguro with 23.9 percent of voting intentions, followed by Cotrim de Figueiredo with 20.8 percent and Ventura with 20.5 percent. Marques Mendes falls to fifth place, with 13.2 percent. Seguro chose, in the Macao SAR, Jorge Neto Valente as his agent, who did not answer HM's call. In a statement published in the newspapers this Wednesday, the former president of the Macau Lawyers Association declared that Seguro “proposes a vision of the future based on the modernization of the country, the valorization of education and a commitment to innovation”. Referring specifically to Portugal-China relations, Neto Valente highlights that “unlike other candidates, Seguro does not support China's provocations regarding the status of Taiwan, and is also a candidate who “knows Portugal, Europe and the world”. Neto Valente also stated that Seguro “is a decent man”. “He participated in all debates, showed politeness, defended his ideas firmly, was never excessive in his language and, unlike others, did not insult opponents or make malicious insinuations toward them.”
A “consistent course” Paulo Pisco, leader of the Insurance campaign for emigration, reminded HM that the candidate “even expressed the opinion that, given that it was an in-person vote [for the presidential elections], the Government could have done much more, namely complying with what the electoral law for the Presidency of the Republic says, which is the possibility of opening more polling stations”. Seguro also defended, according to Paulo Pisco, “that mobility voting could also have been applied, based on the experience previously carried out in the last elections for the European Parliament”. Paulo Pisco states that António José Seguro has followed a “very consistent, solid and objective path”, which has allowed him to reach the top of the polls. Regarding the emigrated electorate, the deputy highlights that Seguro “has not deviated from the purposes, form and values ​​with which he intends to exercise the Presidency of the Republic”. Furthermore, it is “a guarantor of the stability of the political system and also of democracy”. “This image that the candidate António José Seguro has shown throughout his career has earned him greater receptivity from voters”, highlighted Paulo Pisco. The president does not forget that “Seguro is the candidate who has the most representatives per country in our diaspora”. "There are 18, ten in Europe and eight outside Europe. I believe that this substantiates a very firm commitment from the candidate to the exercise of his functions as President of the Republic, and to the relationship he intends to have with the diaspora", he stressed. Looking at the candidates lower down in the polls, we have many faces from the left. The same survey with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January places Catarina Martins, from Bloco de Esquerda, with 2.5 percent; followed by António Filipe, from PCP, with 1.4 percent, head to head with Jorge Pinto, from Livre, who has 1.3 percent. Manuel João Vieira, visual artist and musician, obtains 1 percent of voting intentions.

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. One of the chapters deals with philanthropy in Macau, the discreet profile of philanthropists and the work of entities such as Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino and Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and the historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”.
